item.title: blog 2017-10-02&06 working with a data set 10-2&6
item.description:
OK-so the stupid move for today: website wasn’t building-you have to add in the blogdown library (dumbass).

This blog will just be the text. To see the website (with text) click on the link below:

https://hbeezub.github.io/web_Korean-Confl_1002/

Ok so we sould all be tired of Baseball by now. It is Hockey Season afterall. Go Otters!

go to Kaggle to find an “interesting” data set. We chose US Casualties of the Korean War Data from The U.S. National Archives and Records Administration

We download a csv file (an excel file saed as a csv file)

This had one worksheet with a tremendous amount of information. 36,574 rows of data, each representing a death. When we looked at the file there were a couple of columns that indicted death date. One included deaths AFTER the war, we are only interested in the ones that occured during the war. This is the INCIDENT_DATE column. But not all this data is the date of death. Some of the information in the column is text or zero. Then we determined that if the data in the INCIDENT_DATE is flawed, the date is in the FATALITY column (most of the time).

We want to look at only “good” data (that with a date), and then if the data isn’t “good” we want to look at the fatality colum (but only good data from there as well)

As with all our other projects, we’ll need to install packages & load libraries. In addition, we have to download the csv file (we could only “read” the data in the Lahman database once it was installed-we have to be able to read this new data too)

  • r warning=FALSE,message=FALSE
  • library (dplyr)
  • library(ggplot2)
  • library(stringr)

Since we’ll need all this data in one place, Link to this website to see the results:

https://hbeezub.github.io/web_Korean-Confl_1002/

This blog will just be the text.

so the first thing we need to do in our code is to read the csv file. deaths<-read.csv(‘KoreanConflict.csv’, header=TRUE, stringsAsFactors = FALSE) Stringr automatically sets the factors as columns-we don’t want this so we use the stringsAsFactors=FALSE.

As I mentioned, some of the dates aren’t dates. So we’ll need to make sure that we only want data that is YYYMMDD or 8 digits in length.

‘sum(str_detect(deaths$INCIDENT_DATE,“\d{8}”))’

‘\d means a digit {8} means a pattern of 8 $ means end’

Next we create a for loop to look at the data. If it is good we do nothing. If the date is bad, then we want to look at the fatality column, if that data is good, then we want to use it.

  • for(i in 1:36574){
  • incident<-str_detect(deaths$INCIDENT_DATE[i],“\d{8}”)
  • fatality<-str_detect(deaths$FATALITY[i],“\d{8}”)
  • if(incident==FALSE & fatality==TRUE){
  • deaths\(INCIDENT_DATE[i]<-deaths\)FATALITY[i]
  • }
  • print(i)
  • }

(the in-class example we wrinted the lines-bit we don’t want to do that here) Notice the {} in the for loop for 1 in 1:36574 goes through each row. Incident & fatality are assigned the 8 digit date if it is in the 8 digit format if the incident # is not 8 digits, but the fatality is 8 digits, it makes the fatality number the incident number This code actually changes the data.

Next we want to define the data we’ll use for out line plot:

  • df<-deaths%>%
  • filter(str_detect(deaths$INCIDENT_DATE,“\d{8}”)==TRUE)%>%
  • group_by(INCIDENT_DATE)%>%
  • summarize(num_deaths=n())%>%
  • mutate(date =ymd(INCIDENT_DATE))%>%
  • filter(date<=“1953-07-27”)%>%

  • select(INCIDENT_DATE,num_deaths,date)

  • we aren’t going to worry about the “one failed to parse” warning. The df is our dataframe variable.

The filter is still looking for only 8 digit data (even though we’ve cleaned up the data there are still some problems).

We want to group by the incident dates (date of death)

To count in dplyr we use n().

In order to work with dates, we need to install lubridate. The date fiels we have is actually just a text string of numbers. the “mutate” line takes our digits & puts it into a year format.

The filter date removes any deaths that happened after the Conflict end date of July,27,1953.

Finally we select our data the incident date & the total number of deaths on that date.

If we waht to look at our datafame, type head(df) into the R studio command line. This shows us the top (head) of the data.

Now we’re ready to add our ggplot code:

  • ggplot()+
  • geom_line(data=df, aes(x=date,y=num_deaths))+
  • scale_x_date(date_breaks=‘3 months’,date_labels = “%b%y”)

The scale X code is so that we can label our dates more meaningfully. We did a google search on “strftime” to find the codes we needs (actually listed for Linux)/ %b is the month breakout & %y is the year without the century (last 2 digits).

The next assignment is to make a similar line graph, but group the deaths based on the year the person was born.

Ok so this should be easy-just copy the code & change my parametes.

Not so fast-it took me a while, but with help from google I finally figured it out.

It still takes me a while, but slowly I’m getting it…

Since this is all in the same blog, there is no need to re-load all the libraries.

IN the data base there is a BIRTH_YEAR column. Again, some of the values are blank or are text, so we will need to filter out any “bad” data.

First lets change our “read” for the csv file to brthyr as the variable. We can also look at the birthyear string (now 4 characters)

  • ‘{r warning=FALSE,message=FALSE}’
  • brthyr<-read.csv(‘KoreanConflict.csv’,header=TRUE,stringsAsFactors=FALSE)
  • sum(str_detect(brthyr$BIRTH_YEAR,“\d{4}”))

Next we’ll create our data frame

  • df<-brthyr%>%
  • filter(str_detect(brthyr$BIRTH_YEAR,“\d{4}”)==TRUE)%>%
  • group_by(BIRTH_YEAR)%>%
  • summarize(num_deaths=n())%>%
  • select(BIRTH_YEAR,num_deaths)

we’re using variable df again filtering on the BIRTH_YEAR with only 4 digits grouping by the birthyear summing the numbers with n() and then creating our data with birth year & number of deaths.

  • ggplot()+
  • geom_line(data=df, aes(x=BIRTH_YEAR,y=num_deaths,group=1), stat=“identity”)+
  • geom_point(data=df,aes(x=BIRTH_YEAR,y=num_deaths),stat=“identity”)+
  • theme(axis.text.x=element_text(angle=90,hjust=1))+
  • xlab(“Birth Year”)+
  • ylab(“Number of Deaths”)+
  • ggtitle(“Korean Conflict Deaths by BirthYear”)

OK so this last part is where I started to run into trouble. - geom_line(data=df, aes(x=BIRTH_YEAR,y=num_deaths) Printed the years horizontally along the bottom & did’nt print any data. Quite frustrating I figured out how to rotate the year labels - theme(axis.text.x=element_text(angle=90,hjust=1)) (no Idea what all those things mean (I get sxis, text & angle 90…) My next step was to add the - geom_point(data=df,aes(x=BIRTH_YEAR,y=num_deaths)) Well now I got data, but just the data points (no line) I was getting an error: geom_path: Each group consists of only one observation. Do you need to adjust the group aesthetic?

Back to google again, neither I nor the person posting really knows whay it works, but we add “group=1” and I get a line…

Then I prettied it up with a titel & better XY labels & I am finally done.

It is now 6pm on a Friday night-I’m ready for a glass of Wine! end.

item.title: blog 2017-10-01 flexdashboard 9-29
item.description:
see my flexdashboard https://hbeezub.github.io/web2-2

Check out the above website for soem intering info on Babe Ruth.

item.title: blog 2017-09-28 line plot 9-27
item.description:
A Line graph is great way to show data over time.

Ok we need to go through all the circus of installing packages and bringing them into R studio with library:

library(devtools)
library(Lahman)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggiraph)

We’ll extract some dat afor our time series:

df<-Batting%>%
  filter(playerID=='ruthba01')%>%
  select(yearID,HR)

and add a simple line graph

ggplot()+
  geom_line(data=df, aes(x=yearID, y=HR))

Not too exciting: no title, it would be nice to have some points to know numbers. So let’s to our plotting code:

ggplot()+
  geom_line(data=df, aes(x=yearID, y=HR))+
  geom_point(data=df,aes(x=yearID,y=HR))+
  ggtitle("Babe Ruth HomeRuns")

Now that is definately improved. But wait… there’s more. Act now and we can make this an interactive graph with hover points.

-as a special bonus you get the following included at no additional charge.

The funFact for Today, 9-27-2017 is that Google is 19 years old today. Happy Birthday Google. But even of more note is that yesterday was my 19th wedding anniversary. So my marraige is one day older than Google.

g<-ggplot()+
  geom_line(data=df, aes(x=yearID, y=HR))+
  geom_point_interactive(data=df,aes(x=yearID,y=HR,tooltip=HR,data_id=yearID))+
  ggtitle("Babe Ruth HomeRuns")
                       
ggiraph(code=print(g),hover_css = "fill:white;stroke:blue")

It’s outta here…

item.title: Blog 2017-09-27 Data Visualization Bar Graph round 2
item.description:
Let’s revisit our prior 9-25 post on bar graphs. We will talk a little bit about varaible types. First we need to install packages & load libraries (just like our previous posts):

library(devtools)
library(Lahman)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggiraph)

So when we look at our prior code, we defines a variable called ‘df$name.’ What we want to find out is what type variable it is.

df<-Teams%>%
  filter(yearID==1980)%>%
  select(name,HR)%>%
  arrange(HR)
df$name<-factor(df$name,levels=df$name)

if we type “Teams” into the r studio command line it retuens the information in the table “teams.” if we trple class(Teams) it returns the “type” [1] “data.frame” telling us it is a data frame.

if we type “class(df$name)” into r studio is retuns [1} “factor” as the variable type

factors have levels. again if we type “factor(df$name)” into the Rstudio command line it returns the names of the 25 teams & ends with “26 Levels: New York Mets San Diego Padres … Milwaukee Brewers” Telling us tehre are 26 levels in the factor.

What all this tels us is that we can modify & control the types of variables.

end

item.title: Blog 2017-09-26 Data Visualization Histogram Plot (9-25)
item.description:
OK so the most important thing is to make sure that you ‘save’ the file from class with the working Histogram code. ’Cause if you don’t have that working code, it’s kind of hard to blog about it. Many thanks to Judy for providing the critical piece of informtion that I did not have.

A histogram is a good graph when you have one column of numerical data.

(Again) as with any r-studio project we will need to install packages & then load libraries. In R-studio go to tools (at the top menu bar) click on “install packages”. Type devtool in the pop up box and click on install button. Repeat installation for Lahman, dplyr, ggplot, and ggiraph. To install blogdown. Then bring in the libraries for devtools, Lahman, dplyr, ggplot, and ggiraph.

library(devtools)
library(Lahman)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggiraph)

Now we need some data. Weight: Players weights ovr time would be some interesting data.

df<-Master%>%
  select(weight)

ggplot()+
  geom_histogram(data=df,aes(x=weight))
## `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.
## Warning: Removed 854 rows containing non-finite values (stat_bin).

Ok so the graph looks good, but we’ve got a couple of error messages.

‘Removed 854 rows containing non-finite values (stat_bin)’ That means we’ve got some player data without weight information.

We need to filter out all the blank weights. We use the ! for not:

We’re also getting a bin error: “stat_bin() using bins = 30. Pick better value with binwidth”. That means that we need to have more ‘bars’ or bins to put the data in. (and let’s add a title too)

df<-Master%>%
  filter(!is.na(weight))%>%
  select(weight)
ggplot()+
  geom_histogram(data=df,aes(x=weight),bins=25)+
  ggtitle("Baseball Player Weights")

Ok now that looks pretty good & no errors.

How about a little color:

df<-Master%>%
  filter(!is.na(weight))%>%
  select(weight)

ggplot()+
  geom_histogram(data=df,aes(x=weight),color="White",fill="green",bins=25)+
  ggtitle("Baseball Player Weights")

So that does it for Histograms.
And this is a record blog: only 2 hours.

item.title: Blog 2017-09-25 Data Visualization Bar Graph
item.description:
What else I learned note: Important, when creating a blog, don’t try to copy in info from a word document (the Rmarkdown file doesn’t like it). You’ll only have to scrap what you’ve done & start over.

So now let’s explore a bar chart.

As with any r-studio project we will need to install packages & then load libraries. In R-studio go to tools (at the top menu bar) click on “install packages”. Type devtool in the pop up box and click on install button. Repeat installation for Lahman, dplyr, ggplot, and ggiraph. To install blogdown. Then bring in the libraries for devtools, Lahman, dplyr, ggplot, and ggiraph.

library(devtools)
library(Lahman)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggiraph)

Now we need some data. How about the total team Home Runs from 1980. The summer of 1980 I had just finished my Freshman year of High School; I was officially a Sophmore (ie wise fool).

df<-Teams%>%
  filter(yearID==1980)%>%
  select(name,HR)

As in our scatter plot (previous post) we’ve defined our data with “df<-”. The “%>%”" is a continuation character.

The basic graph is next. With the bar chart we need to add “stat=‘identity’”:

ggplot()+
  geom_bar(data=df,aes(x=name,y=HR),stat="identity")

Whoa

Well, we have a graph, but we can’t read the team names on the bottom. We need to flip the axis.

ggplot()+
  geom_bar(data=df,aes(x=name,y=HR),stat="identity")+
  coord_flip()

Much Better Now, I really can’t tell (easily) if the Astros had more Home Runs than the Padres. What we need to do is to put these in order.

Simply, adding “arrange” to the dplyr code for our base data didn’t work. So what we need to do is add in a factor.

df<-Teams%>%
  filter(yearID==1980)%>%
  select(name,HR)%>%
  arrange(HR)
df$name<-factor(df$name,levels=df$name)
ggplot()+
  geom_bar(data=df,aes(x=name,y=HR),stat="identity")+
  coord_flip()

Now we’re cooking with gas

Ok let’s add some color and we’re done:

df<-Teams%>%
  filter(yearID==1980)%>%
  select(name,HR)%>%
  arrange(HR)
df$name<-factor(df$name,levels=df$name)
ggplot()+
  geom_bar(data=df,aes(x=name,y=HR),stat="identity",color="blue",fill="white")+
  coord_flip()

end

item.title: Blog 2017-09-24 Data Visualization (blog#2.4)
item.description:
OK so this is attempt 4 for this blog post. So my AHa shower moment was “I’m using the wrong file format.” Sure enough, I was using an “.md” file, but I needed a “.Rmd” file. Ok so then I was still having issues (well, I have issues so let’s clarify-issues with the site giving me an error when I tried to build it). So copy someone elses work & make changes so that it fits your original intent (& it isn’t plagiarism -btw-thank’s Jorge). So now we’re cooking with gas. I can get rid of the info I don’t understand & add things like summary & the site will build. Yes & I figured out (on my own) how to get that “build” bold).

The text is the same, but this time I have the code inserted that I want.

We used R-studio to create a scatter plot of baseball information (from the Lahman library). Aside from learning how to do the scatter plot, the most interesting thing I learned is that the “css” that I keep seeing in the sample blog has to do with viewing the HTML information. I had been wondering what all of them were (and now I know)

I. Our first step was to open r-studio and install all the packages we would need and then bring them all in with ‘library’:

library(devtools)
library(Lahman)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggiraph)
  1. We pulled some interesting information: players with more than 400 career Home runs, but we also wanted to know the number of strikeouts too. We used the following code:
df<-Batting %>%
  group_by(playerID)%>%
  summarize(career_HR=sum(HR), career_SO=sum(SO))%>%
  filter(career_HR >=400)
  1. We then created our graph using ggplot, in the same way that the ‘%>%’ is the continuation character for r markdown, the ‘+’ is the continuation character for ggplot. the ‘aes’ (asthetic) is for the xy axis. The geom_point indicates we want a scatter plot (points). If we wanted some other type, like a bar chart we would use geom_bar. ggtitle gives our graph it’s name, and the xlab & ylab (label) give the axes names.
HR_vs_SO<-inner_join(df,Master,by=c("playerID"))%>%
  select(nameFirst,nameLast,career_HR,career_SO)

g<-ggplot()+
  geom_point_interactive(data=HR_vs_SO,aes(x=career_SO,y=career_HR))+
  ggtitle("Career Home Runs vs Strike Outs for Great Hitlers.")+
  xlab("Career Strikeouts")+
  ylab("Career Homeruns")

Again we want to ‘save’ this so we name it (like we did the batting information) ‘g<-’ before ggplot.

This gives us a nice visual, but we don’t know what (or rather who) the points represent.

  1. So we use colnames(master) to find out the table names in the Lahman information. Now we want to ‘paste’ together the first & last names. The following code is added to the ‘Batting’ code to show the first & last names:
HR_vs_SO<-inner_join(df,Master,by=c('playerID'))%>%
  select(nameFirst,nameLast,career_HR,career_SO)

‘V.’ Now we add a little more code we define the name as a tool tip & modify our gg plot code so that as we hover over our points, we get the names:

geom_point_interactive(data=HR_vs_SO,aes(x=career_SO,y=career_HR,tooltip=name, data_id=nameLast))

and add some color to our visual:

ggiraph(code=print(g),hover_css=“Fill:white;stroke:blue”)

VI.Ok, so the final code looks like this:

df<-Batting%>%
  group_by(playerID)%>%
  summarize(career_HR=sum(HR),career_SO=sum(SO))%>%
  filter(career_HR >= 400)

HR_vs_SO<-inner_join(df,Master,by=c("playerID"))%>%
  select(nameFirst,nameLast,career_HR,career_SO)

HR_vs_SO$name<-paste(HR_vs_SO$nameFirst,HR_vs_SO$nameLast)

g<-ggplot()+
  geom_point_interactive(data=HR_vs_SO,aes(x=career_SO,y=career_HR,tooltip=nameLast,data_id=nameLast))+
  ggtitle("Career Home Runs vs Strike Outs for Great Hitlers.")+
  xlab("Career Strikeouts")+
  ylab("Career Homeruns")

ggiraph(code=print(g),hover_css="Fill:white;stroke:blue")

item.title: blog 2017-09-21 -My first blog
item.description:
So instead of being able to create a website in an hour, so far I’ve spent 8 (over 2 days). I keep getting errors!!!!! Hopefully I will have it now. My goal will be to change one thing (file) and worry about any other changes tomorrow. Tomorrow, tomorrow, there’s always tomorrow…

OK so now instead of being able to comment out the table of contents it just added the <!- (not even a second dash).

Now I am REALLY irritated that this is not working.

Alright, I got MOST of it gone (another 30 minutes of my life).

Key features:

I like this simple design with the bold colors
